title: 109_s1963
content: The Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvement Act of 2005 includes provisions for calculation of separation tolled during litigation, establishment of Trade Adjustment Assistance Advisor, certification of submissions, revision of eligibility criteria, training, funding for administrative costs, and authorization of appropriations. It also covers data collection, study, information to workers, determinations by the Secretary of Labor, and assistance for farmers including clarification of marketing year and eligibility. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvement Act of 2005 amends the Trade Act of 1974 to include a special rule for calculating separation during litigation and the establishment of a Trade Adjustment Assistance Advisor. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvement Act of 2005 establishes the Office of the Trade Adjustment Assistance Advisor within the Department of Labor to provide technical and legal assistance to individuals or entities seeking certification under section 221. SEC. 103. Certification of Submissions requires employers to certify the accuracy and completeness of evidence or information submitted for worker petitions. SEC. 104. Revision of Eligibility Criteria is also addressed in the Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvement Act of 2005. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include shifts in production to foreign countries and eligibility for wage insurance under the alternative trade adjustment assistance program. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include eligibility criteria for wage insurance under the alternative trade adjustment assistance program, such as age, income, full-time employment, and not returning to previous employment. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Act. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include eligibility criteria for wage insurance under the alternative trade adjustment assistance program. Section 222(c)(3) is amended to remove certain certification requirements for downstream workers. SEC. 105. TRAINING. Modification of enrollment deadlines and extension of allowance for training under the Trade Act of 1974 are amended to allow for longer deadlines and additional weeks of allowance for delayed training enrollment. Funding for training is also addressed in the amendments. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow adversely affected workers to have training costs covered by the Secretary, including costs incurred before certification. The Secretary is required to develop a training program approval process within 6 months of the Trade Adjustment Assistance Improvement Act of 2005. The Secretary must develop a formula for individual training cost entitlements for workers under trade adjustment assistance, taking into account various factors. Until Congress approves the formula, payments cannot exceed fifty percent of trade readjustment allowances. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include integrated workforce training and entrepreneurial training programs. Integrated workforce training combines occupational skills training with English language acquisition. SEC. 106 amends Section 241 of the Trade Act of 1974 to ensure that funds provided by the Secretary to a State cover all administrative costs related to operating the trade adjustment assistance program. SEC. 107 authorizes appropriations for these purposes. SEC. 107 authorizes appropriations for the Trade Adjustment Assistance program, amending various sections of the Trade Act of 1974 to update funding amounts and years. This is part of the "Trade Adjustment Assistance Accountability Act." SEC. 250 outlines data collection, evaluations, and reporting requirements. The Secretary will collect necessary data and establish a performance evaluation system for the trade adjustment assistance program. This includes comparing program performance before and after the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reform Act of 2002 in terms of workers certified, processing times, training waivers, and program coordination. The Secretary will collect data to evaluate the effectiveness of training providers, states' implementation of health care coverage options, and the trade adjustment assistance program for eligible individuals. Other necessary data will also be gathered for program evaluation. The Secretary will collect data to evaluate the effectiveness of the trade adjustment assistance program, including the number of workers receiving benefits, types of benefits, training enrollment, duration of training, and earnings history of workers. The Secretary will collect data on wages before and after separation, reemployment rates, causes of dislocation, and the number of petitions filed in each congressional district. State participation in the performance measurement system will be incentivized. The Trade Adjustment Assistance Accountability Act requires states to supplement employment and wage data with unemployment insurance records. States must monitor internal control measures for performance data and improve the speed and quality of rapid responses. The Secretary must submit reports to relevant committees within 6 months of the Act's enactment. The Committee on Ways and Means of the House of Representatives requires a report that describes the performance measurement system, includes data analysis, and provides program improvement recommendations. The Secretary must submit an annual report to the Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee, along with releasing it to the public. The Secretary is required to submit an annual report to Congress and the public, detailing state participation in programs and data collected for performance evaluation. The data gathered will be made available to each State, Congress, and the public. Amendments are made to ensure coordination with the Trade Act of 1974. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include the Departments of Labor, Commerce, and Agriculture in various sections. Additionally, the table of contents for title II is updated to reflect these changes. Title III of the Trade Act of 1974 focuses on Trade Adjustment Assistance for Farmers, including provisions related to marketing year clarification. The amendments made by this section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Labor is required to publish determinations on petitions promptly in the Federal Register and make the full text available on the Department of Labor's website. Section 301 clarifies the marketing year for agricultural commodities and extends adjustment assistance to fishermen harvesting wild stock under the Trade Act of 1974. Section 302 addresses eligibility for assistance. Section 302 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to increase eligibility requirements to 90 percent and includes provisions for farmers with no positive net farm income in the past two years without adjustment assistance.
